column1: 24*{'text': 'The Roman war against Numidia and Mauretania ends with their annexation.'
24*{'text': 'Servius Cornelius Cethegus and Lucius Visellius Varro become consuls.'
24*{'text': 'Charmides becomes Archon of Athens.'
24*{'text': "Tacfarinas' revolt in Africa is repressed."
24*{'text': 'Philo declares that the Old Testament is the eternal law of God.'
25*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius settles a dispute between Messenia and Sparta over the Ager Dentheliales on Mount Taygetus
25*{'text': 'Lucius Aelius Sejanus unsuccessfully attempts to marry the widow of Drusus Julius Caesar.'
25*{'text': 'Cossus Cornelius Lentulus
25*{'text': 'The Han dynasty is restored in China as Liu Xiu proclaims himself Emperor
25*{'text': 'Luoyang becomes the capital of the Houhan or Eastern Han Dynasty.'
25*{'text': 'Pomponius Mela formalizes the climatic zone system.'
26*{'text': 'Pontius Pilate is appointed as prefect of Judea.'
26*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius retires to Capri
column2: leaving the Praetorian Guard under Lucius Aelius Sejanus in charge of the Roman Empire and the city of Rome.'

column1: 27*{'text': 'Lucius Calpurnius Piso and Marcus Licinius Crassus Frugi become Roman consuls.'
27*{'text': 'Fire in Rome.'
27*{'text': 'A poorly built amphitheatre in Fidenae collapses
27*{'text': 'An Arc of Triumph is erected in Rimini
27*{'text': 'Baptism of Jesus
20*{'text': 'Servius Sulpicius Galba is a Roman praetor.'
20*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius is forced to order an investigation and a public trial in the Roman Senate
20*{'text': 'Marcus Valerius Messalla Barbatus becomes a consul.'
20*{'text': 'First year of Dihuang era of the Chinese Xin Dynasty.'
20*{'text': 'Philo defines philosophy as the maidservant of theology.'
21*{'text': 'Revolt of the Aedui under Julius Florus and Julius Sacrovir
21*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius is a Roman Consul for the fourth time.'
21*{'text': 'The Romans create a buffer state in the territory of the Quadi in southern Slovakia.'
21*{'text': 'The manufacture of pens and metal writing tools begins in Rome.'
22*{'text': 'The consuls are Decimus Haterius Agrippa and Gaius Sulpicius Galba.'
22*{'text': 'Marcus Cocceius Nerva and Gaius Vibius Rufinus are consuls Ex Kal.'
22*{'text': 'Drusus Julius Caesar receives the tribunicia potestas (tribunician power).'
23*{'text': "Emperor Tiberius' son Julius Caesar Drusus dies."
23*{'text': 'Lucius Aelius Sejanus begins to dominate the Roman Senate and Tiberius
23*{'text': 'Gaius Asinius Pollio and Gaius Antistius Vetus become consuls.'
23*{'text': 'Liu Xuan
column2: a descendant of the Han Dynasty royal family and leader of insurgents against the Xin Dynasty
column3: proclaims himself emperor against Wang Mang.'

column1: 28*{'text': 'The Frisians negotiate a treaty with the Romans at the River Rhine
29*{'text': 'The Romans capture Serdica (modern Sofia)
column2: named after the Celtic tribe the Serdi.'

column1: 29*{'text': 'Agrippina the Elder is exiled to the island of Pandataria
column2: and her sons (except Caligula) are imprisoned by Lucius Aelius Sejanus.'

column1: 29*{'text': 'Jesus baptized by John the Baptist (see 27).'
4*{'text': 'Emperor Caesar Augustus summons Tiberius to Rome
column2: and names him his heir and future emperor.'

column1: 4*{'text': 'Tiberius also adopts Germanicus as his own heir.'
4*{'text': 'Sextus Aelius Catus becomes consul.'
4*{'text': 'The Lex Aelia Sentia regulates the manumission of slaves.'
4*{'text': 'A pact of non-aggression and friendship is signed between the Roman Empire
column3: and the German tribe the Cherusci

column1: 4*{'text': 'Julia the Elder returns from exile to live in Rhegium in disgrace.'
4*{'text': 'Augustus pardons Gnaeus Cornelius Cinna Magnus
column3: the daughter of Marcus Aemilius Lepidus
column4: for alleged involvement in a conspiracy against the emperor.'

column1: 4*{'text': 'Marcus Plautius Silvanus is appointed as proconsul of Asia.'
4*{'text': 'Polianus Maradonius becomes Archon of Athens.'
4*{'text': 'Namhae Chachaung succeeds Bak Hyeokgeose as king of the Korean kingdom of Silla (traditional date).'
4*{'text': 'Emperor Ping of Han marries Empress Wang (Ping)
4*{'text': 'Wang Mang is given the title "Superior Duke".'
4*{'text': 'Nicolaus of Damascus writes the 15 volume History of the World.'
8*{'text': 'Vipsania Julia is exiled.'
8*{'text': 'Marcus Furius Camillus
column3: and Lucius Apronius become Roman Consuls.'

column1: 8*{'text': 'Tincomarus
column3: flees Britain for Rome; Eppillus becomes king.'

column1: 8*{'text': 'Start of Chushi era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.'
59*{'text': 'Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus retires from the Roman Senate.'
59*{'text': 'Emperor Nero ordered the murder of his mother Agrippina the Younger.'
59*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo
59*{'text': 'Paul the Apostle pleads his case and testifies of Christianity before king Agrippa II.'
58*{'text': 'The friendship between Nero and Marcus Salvius Otho ends when they both fall in love with Poppea Sabina
column2: and Otho is sent to Lusitania as governor.'

column1: 58*{'text': 'Corbulo marched to Artaxata crossing the Aras River
column2: along the valley he is shadowed by tens of thousands of mounted Parthian archers led by king Tiridates I.'

column1: 58*{'text': 'The Ficus Ruminalis begins to die (see Rumina).'
58*{'text': 'Gnaeus Julius Agricola
column3: is serving as a military tribune in Britain under Gaius Suetonius Paulinus and is attached to Legio II Augusta.'

column1: 58*{'text': 'Start of Yongping era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.'
58*{'text': 'The apostle Paul is arrested in Jerusalem
58*{'text': 'St. Paul writes his Epistle to the Romans.'
55*{'text': 'Agrippina the Younger is expelled from the imperial palace by her son Nero
column2: who installs her in Villa Antonia in Misenum.'

column1: 55*{'text': 'The Roman jurist Sabinus writes three books on the rights of citizens.'
55*{'text': 'The apostle Paul writes his First Epistle to the Corinthians.'
54*{'text': 'Nero attempts to prohibit the gladiatorial games.'
54*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo arrives in the East and take up an assignment as governor of Asia
column2: with a secret brief from Nero and his chief ministers Seneca and Burrus to return Armenia to the Roman Empire.'

column1: 54*{'text': 'Corbulo inspects in Syria a base of Legio X Fretensis at Cyrrhus
column2: the Roman legionnaires are demoralized by a "long peace".'

column1: 54*{'text': 'Corbulo recruits Syrian auxiliary units in the region and stationed them in border forts
column2: with orders from Nero not to provoke the Parthians.'

column1: 54*{'date': 'Winter'
column2: 'text': 'Domitius Corbulo marched his legions (Legio VI Ferrata and Legio X) into the mountains of Cappadocia and made camp.'

column1: 54*{'text': "Judea is returned piecemeal to Agrippa I's son Marcus Julius Agrippa between 48 and 54."
54*{'text': 'Patriarch Onesimus succeeds Stachys the Apostle as Patriarch of Constantinople.'
54*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus begins his third mission.'
54*{'text': 'Apollos
column3: is converted to Christianity in Ephesus.'

column1: 57*{'text': 'Oldest evidence of writing in Japan (see Hanko).'
57*{'text': 'A Japanese king sends an ambassador to China.'
57*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus writes his Second Epistle to the Corinthians and his Epistle to the Romans (probable date).'
56*{'text': 'Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus becomes a consul in Rome.'
56*{'text': 'The Jianwu era of the Eastern Han Dynasty changes to the Jianwuzhongyuan era.'
51*{'text': 'Emperor Claudius and Titus Flavius Vespasianus are Roman Consuls.'
51*{'text': 'Burrus
column3: is charged by Seneca with the education of Nero.'

column1: 51*{'text': "The captured Caratacus is exhibited in chains in Claudius' triumph in Rome
column2: but his dignified demeanour persuades the emperor to spare his life and allow his family to live free in the capital for short period of time."

column1: 51*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus begins his second mission (approximate date).'
51*{'text': 'The New Testament book 1 Thessalonians is written (possible date).'
50*{'text': 'Cologne is raised to the status of a city.'
50*{'text': 'Utrecht is founded
column2: a Roman fortification (castellum) is constructed at the Rhine border in the present-day Netherlands.'

column1: 50*{'text': 'Claudius adopts Nero.'
50*{'text': 'The Iazyges settle in the Hungarian plain to the east of the Tisza River.'
50*{'text': 'The Tocharian or Yue-Chi tribes are united under the Kushan leader Kujula Kadphises
column2: thus creating the Kushan Empire in Afghanistan and northern India.'

column1: 50*{'text': 'The Epistle to the Romans is written (approximate date).'
50*{'text': 'The Apostles hold the Council of Jerusalem (approximate date).'
50*{'text': 'Hero of Alexandria invents a steam turbine (possible date).'
50*{'text': 'Pamphilus of Alexandria writes a poetic lexicon.'
50*{'text': 'Pedanius Dioscorides describes the medical applications of plants in De Materia Medica.'
50*{'text': 'The distinction between chronic maladies and acute illnesses is made by Thessalos.'
53*{'text': 'Decimus Junius Silanus Torquatus and Quintus Haterius Antoninus become Roman consuls.'
53*{'text': 'Claudius secures a senatorial decree that gives jurisdiction in financial cases to imperial procurators.'
53*{'text': 'Nero marries Claudia Octavia.'
53*{'text': 'Claudius accepts Nero as his successor
column3: his son by his first wife

column1: 53*{'text': 'Distinct fellowships within the reign of centricles fall to the dominion of Gaulic barbarians
column2: which provoked an enclave uprising in the foothills of what are now the Alps.'

column1: 53*{'text': 'Evodius succeeds Saint Peter as Patriarch of Antioch.'
53*{'text': 'Seneca writes the tragedy Agamemnon
column2: which he intends to be read as the last chapter of a trilogy including two of his other tragedies

column1: 52*{'text': 'Emperor Claudius attempts to control the Fucine Lake by digging a 5
52*{'text': 'Ananias
column3: is sent to Rome after being accused of violence.'

column1: 52*{'text': 'Barea Soranus is consul suffectus in Rome.'
52*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder writes his account of the German wars.'
52*{'text': 'The Yuejue Shu
column2: the first known gazetteer of China
column3: is written during the Han Dynasty.'

column1: 52*{'text': 'Saint Thomas
column2: one of the twelve disciples of Jesus
column3: is believed to have landed in Kodungallur
column4: India to preach the Gospel; the Marthoma Church
column7: and the Assyrian Church of the East claim descent from him.'

column1: 88*{'text': 'Emperor Han Zhangdi dies at age 31 after a 13-year reign in which Chinese military forces have become powerful enough to march against tribes who threaten their northern and western borders.'
88*{'text': 'Pope Clement I succeeds Pope Anacletus I as the fourth pope.'
89*{'text': 'Legio XIII Gemina is transferred to Dacia to help in the war against Decebalus.'
89*{'text': 'Aquincum (old Budapest
89*{'text': 'First year of Yongyuan era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.'
89*{'date': 'June'
column2: 'text': 'The Han Chinese army under Dou Xian (d. 92)
column4: is victorious over the Northern Xiongnu in the Battle of Ikh Bayan.'

column1: 89*{'text': 'Change of Patriarch of Constantinople from Polycarpus to Plutarch.'
82*{'text': 'Gnaeus Julius Agricola raises a fleet and encircles the Celtic tribes beyond the Forth
column2: the Caledonians rise in great numbers against the Romans.'

column1: 82*{'text': 'Calgacus unites the Picts (30
column2: 000 men) in Scotland and is made chieftain of the Caledonian Confederacy.'

column1: 82*{'text': "Dio Chrysostom is banished from Rome
column3: and Bithynia after advising one of the Emperor's conspiring relatives."

column1: 83*{'text': 'Inchtuthil
80*{'text': 'Emperor Titus inaugurates the Colosseum with 100 days of games.'
80*{'text': 'The earliest stage of Lullingstone Roman villa is built.'
80*{'text': 'The Roman occupation of Britain reaches the River Tyne–Solway Firth frontier area.'
80*{'text': 'Legio II Adiutrix is stationed at Lindum Colonia (modern Lincoln).'
80*{'text': 'The original Roman Pantheon is destroyed in a fire
80*{'text': 'The Eifel Aqueduct is constructed to bring water 95\xa0km (59\xa0mi) from the Eifel region to Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensum (modern Cologne).'
80*{'text': 'Some 30
column2: 000 Asian tribespeople migrate from the steppes to the west with 40
column5: joining with Iranian tribespeople and with Mongols from the Siberian forests to form a group that will be known in Europe as the Huns.'

column1: 80*{'text': 'The aeolipile
column3: is described by Hero of Alexandria.'

column1: 80*{'text': 'The Gospel of Luke and Acts of the Apostles are written (approximate date).'
81*{'text': 'The Arch of Titus is constructed.'
81*{'text': 'Pliny the Younger is flamen Divi Augusti (priest in the cult of the Emperor).'
81*{'text': 'The silver content of the Roman denarius rises to 92 percent under emperor Domitian
column2: up from 81 percent in the reign of Vitellius.'

column1: 86*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian introduces the Capitoline Games.'
86*{'text': 'The Roman General Trajan
column3: begins a campaign to crush an uprising in Germany.'

column1: 86*{'text': 'Germany is divided into two provinces
86*{'text': 'Ban Gu (Pan Kou) and his sister Ban Zhao (Pan Tchao) compose a History of China.'
87*{'text': 'The Roman Maternus arrives in Ethiopia.'
87*{'text': 'Lyon
87*{'text': 'Sextus gains power in the senate.'
87*{'text': 'Decebalus becomes king of Dacia.'
84*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian recalls Agricola back to Rome
column2: where he is rewarded with a triumph and the governorship of the Roman province Africa

column1: 84*{'text': 'Pliny the Younger is sevir equitum Romanorum (commander of a cavalry squadron).'
84*{'text': 'The construction of the Limes
column2: a line of Roman fortifications from the Rhine to the Danube

column1: 84*{'text': 'Change of Jianchu era to Yuanhe era of the Chinese Eastern Han Dynasty.'
85*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian repulses a Dacian invasion of Moesia.'
85*{'text': 'Baekje invades the outskirts of Silla in the Korean peninsula.'
3*{'text': 'The rule of emperor Augustus is renewed for a ten-year period.'
3*{'text': 'Augustus adopts his grandson
column3: with the expectation that he will succeed him.'

column1: 3*{'text': 'Lucius Aelius Lamia and Marcus Valerius Messalla Messallinus are consuls of Rome.'
3*{'text': 'Menneas becomes Archon of Athens.'
3*{'text': "Wang Mang foils a plot by his son
column5: and the Wei clan to oust him from the regent's position."

column1: 7*{'text': 'Publius Quinctilius Varus is appointed governor of Germania.'
7*{'text': 'Tiberius Quinctilius Varus
column3: is charged with organizing Germania between the Rhine and Elbe rivers.'

column1: 7*{'text': 'Abgarus of Edessa is deposed as king of Osroene.'
7*{'text': "Zhai Yi
column2: Governor of the Commandery of Dong (modern Puyang

column1: 7*{'text': 'Wang Mang puts down the rebellion during the winter.'
100*{'text': 'Emperor Trajan and Sextus Julius Frontinus become Roman Consuls.'
100*{'text': 'Pliny the Younger advances to consulship
column2: giving his panegyric on Trajan in the process.'

column1: 100*{'text': 'The Roman Army reaches 300
100*{'text': "Tiberius Avidius Quietus' rule as governor of Roman Britain ends."
100*{'text': 'Timgad (Thamugas)
column2: a Roman colonial town in North Africa is founded by Trajan.'

column1: 100*{'text': 'Trajan creates a policy intended to restore the former economic supremacy of Italy.'
100*{'text': 'The Kingdom of Himyarite is conquered by the Hadramaut.'
100*{'text': 'The Hopewell tradition begins in what is now Ohio circa this date.'
100*{'text': 'Teotihuacan
100*{'text': 'The Moche civilization emerges
column2: and starts building a society in present-day Peru.'

column1: 100*{'text': 'Main hall
100*{'text': 'The Gospel of John is widely believed to have been written around this date.'
100*{'text': 'The compilation of the Kama sutra begins in India.'
100*{'text': 'The Temple of the God of Medicine is built in Anguo
100*{'text': 'The Fourth Buddhist Council is convened circa this year.'
39*{'text': "Tigellinus
column2: minister and favorite of the later Roman emperor Nero
column3: is banished for adultery with Caligula's sisters."

column1: 39*{'text': 'Gaius Caesar Augustus Germanicus (Caligula) and Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo become Roman consuls.'
39*{'text': 'Domitius Afer secures a consulship.'
39*{'text': 'Agrippa I
39*{'text': 'Legio XV Primigenia and XXII Primigenia are levied by Caligula for the German frontier.'
39*{'text': "Caligula's campaign into Germany is stopped by a conspiracy led by Cassius Chaerea."
39*{'text': 'Caligula orders that a statue of himself be placed in the temple in Jerusalem.'
39*{'text': 'Philo leads a Jewish delegation to Rome to protest the anti-Jewish conditions in Alexandria.'
39*{'text': 'The Trung Sisters resist the Chinese influences in Vietnam.'
38*{'text': 'Phaedrus writes his popular collection of fables.'
33*{'text': 'Servius Sulpicius Galba is a Roman Consul.'
33*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius founds a credit bank in Rome.'
33*{'text': 'A financial crisis hits Rome
column2: due to poorly chosen fiscal policies.'

column1: 32*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus and Lucius Arruntius Camillus Scribonianus become Roman consuls.'
32*{'text': 'Saint Peter traditionally becomes first pope (see 30 for more likely date).'
32*{'text': 'Symbolic interpretation of the OT by Philo (Allegory).'
31*{'text': 'Lucius Aelius Sejanus is named co-Consul to the Emperor Tiberius.'
31*{'text': 'Naevius Sutorius Macro becomes the leader of the Praetorian Guard after Sejanus is executed.'
31*{'text': 'Tiberius returns to Rome from Capri.'
31*{'text': 'Jared conquers the Babylonians according to the Dead Sea Scrolls.'
30*{'text': 'The Romans found the city of Tournai in Belgium.'
30*{'text': 'The Kushan Empire is founded (approximate date).'
30*{'text': 'The Sermon on the Mount (according to proponents of the 33 theory
30*{'text': "Phaedrus translates Aesop's fables
column2: and composes some of his own."

column1: 30*{'text': 'Velleius Paterculus writes the general history of the countries known in Antiquity.'
37*{'date': 'March 18'
column2: 'text': "The Roman Senate annuls Tiberius's will and proclaims Caligula Roman Emperor."

column1: 37*{'text': "Caligula's attempt to have himself deified creates friction between himself and the Senate."
37*{'date': 'April 9'
37*{'text': 'Abilene is granted to Agrippa I.'
37*{'text': 'Saint Peter founds the Syrian Orthodox Church (traditional date).'
36*{'text': 'Pontius Pilate is recalled to Rome after putting down a Samaritan uprising.'
36*{'text': 'Lucius Vitellius defeats Artabanus II of Parthia in support of another clamaint to the throne
36*{'text': "Herod Antipas suffers major losses in a war with Aretas IV of Nabatea
column2: provoked partly by Antipas' divorce of Aretas' daughter."

column1: 36*{'text': 'Marcellus becomes governor of Judaea and Samaria.'
35*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder is brought to Rome before this year.'
34*{'text': 'Paullus Fabius Persicus and Lucius Vitellius become Roman consuls.'
34*{'text': 'Naevius Sutorius Macro is said to gain favour in the empire by prostituting his wife Eunius to Caligula.'
34*{'text': 'St. Paul and St. Barnabas start preaching the gospel to the Gentiles.'
34*{'text': 'The original inhabitants of Dacia revolt against the Sarmatian tribe of Iazyges who had enslaved them.'
60*{'text': 'Prasutagus
column3: made a will and left his kingdom to his two daughters and emperor Nero.'

column1: 60*{'text': 'The Icenian chiefs are deprived of their hereditary estates
column2: the Roman army annexed East Anglia.'

column1: 60*{'text': 'Boudica
column3: is flogged and then forced to witness the public rape of her daughters.'

column1: 60*{'text': 'Gaius Suetonius Paulinus
column3: leads a campaign on the island of Mona (Anglesey).'

column1: 60*{'text': 'Boudica joins the British Celtic tribes in revolt
60*{'text': 'The rebels defeat Legio IX Hispana and destroyed the capital Camulodunum (modern Colchester).'
60*{'text': 'Boudica sacks Londinium (London) and Verulamium (St Albans).'
60*{'text': 'Nero send an expedition to explore the historical city Meroë (Sudan).'
60*{'text': 'The Rhoxolani are defeated on the Danube by the Romans.'
60*{'text': 'Vitellius is (possibly) proconsul of Africa.'
60*{'text': 'Herod Agrippa II rules the northeast of Judea.'
60*{'text': 'The First Epistle of Peter
column3: is probably written between this year and c. 64.'

column1: 60*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus journeys to Rome
60*{'text': 'Hero of Alexandria writes Metrica
61*{'text': 'Publius Petronius Turpilianus and Lucius Caesennius Paetus become Roman consuls.'
61*{'text': 'The Druidic stronghold of Anglesey in north Wales is attacked and destroyed by Suetonius Paulinus (Tacitus
61*{'text': 'Boudica
column3: leads a Celtic revolt in Britain.'

column1: 61*{'text': 'Galba becomes governor of Hispania Tarraconensis.'
62*{'text': 'Emperor Nero marries for the second time
62*{'text': 'A great earthquake damages cities in Campania
62*{'text': 'The Parthians invade Armenia and lay siege to Tigranocerta.'
62*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo strengthens the fortifications on the Euphrates frontier.'
62*{'text': 'Lucius Caesennius Paetus advances towards Tigranocerta
column2: but by lack of supplies he makes camp for the winter in the fortress at Rhandeia in northwestern Armenia.'

column1: 62*{'text': 'A violent storm destroys 200 ships in the port of Portus.'
62*{'text': 'Lucan writes a history of the conflict between Julius Caesar and Pompey.'
62*{'text': 'The making of Still Life
column2: a detail of a wall painting from Herculaneum

column1: 62*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus is imprisoned in Rome (approximate date).'
63*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo is restored to command after the Roman debacle at the Battle of Rhandeia; he invaded Armenia and defeated Tiridates I
column2: who accepted Roman sovereignty; Parthia withdrew from the war.'

column1: 63*{'text': 'Pompeii the city at the foot of Mount Vesuvius
column2: is heavily damaged by a strong earthquake.'

column1: 63*{'text': 'Aulus Cornelius Celsus writes a dictionary (encyclopedia) on the arts and sciences.'
64*{'text': 'Nero proposes a new urban planning program based the creation of buildings decorated with ornate porticos
column2: the widening of the streets and the use of open spaces.'

column1: 64*{'text': 'Lyon sends a large sum of money to Rome to aid in the reconstruction.'
64*{'text': 'Phoenicia becomes part of Syria.'
64*{'text': 'The Kushan sack the town of Taxila (in present-day Pakistan).'
64*{'text': 'The year the First Epistle of Peter is traditionally believed to be written.'
64*{'text': 'Seneca proclaims the equality of all men
65*{'text': 'Gaius Calpurnius Piso conspires against Roman emperor Nero.'
65*{'text': 'Cestius Gallus becomes legate of Syria.'
65*{'text': 'Nero kills his pregnant wife
column3: with a kick to the stomach.'

column1: 65*{'text': 'The Gospel of Matthew is probably written between 60 and this year.'
65*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus ordains Timothy as bishop of Ephesus (traditional date).'
65*{'text': 'The first Christian community in Africa is founded by Mark
66*{'date': 'September 22'
column2: 'text': 'Emperor Nero creates the legion I Italica.'

column1: 66*{'text': 'The Jewish Revolt (66–70 AD) commences against the Roman Empire.'
66*{'text': 'The Zealots lay siege on Jerusalem and annihilate the Roman garrison (a cohort of Legio III).'
66*{'text': 'The Sicarii capture the fortress of Masada overlooking the Dead Sea.'
66*{'text': 'Cestius Gallus
column3: marches into Judea and leads a Roman army of 28
column4: 000 soldiers to put down the Jewish rebellion.'

column1: 66*{'date': 'November'
column2: 'text': 'Gallus succeeds in conquering Beit She\'arim "the new city"
column3: but is unable to take the Temple in Jerusalem.'

column1: 66*{'text': 'Gallus arrives in Caesarea
column2: with six thousand men and numerous standards
column3: including the eagle of Legio XII.'

column1: 66*{'text': 'The Roman Legion II Augusta is stationed at Gloucester.'
66*{'text': 'Suetonius Paullinus becomes a Roman Consul.'
66*{'text': 'Baekje invades Silla in the Korean peninsula
66*{'text': 'The First Epistle to Timothy is written (approximate date).'
66*{'text': 'Dioscorides writes his De Materia Medica
column2: a treatise on the methodical treatment of disease by use of medicine.'

column1: 66*{'text': "Halley's Comet is visible."
67*{'text': 'Gaius Licinius Mucianus replaces Cestius Gallus as governor of Syria.'
67*{'text': 'Siege of Jotapata and massacre of its 40
67*{'text': 'Fall of the Jewish fortress of Gamla in the Golan to the Romans and massacre of its inhabitants.'
67*{'text': 'Nero travels to Greece
column2: where he participates in the Olympic Games and other festivals.'

column1: 67*{'text': 'Sardinia becomes a Roman province.'
67*{'text': 'Nero
column2: jealous of the success of Corbulo in Armenia
column3: orders that he be put to death.'

column1: 67*{'text': 'Martyrdom of apostles Saint Peter and Saint Paul.'
67*{'text': 'Pope Linus succeeds Saint Peter as the second pope (in Catholic reckoning).'
68*{'date': 'June 8'
68*{'text': 'Legio I Macriana liberatrix and Legio I Adiutrix are created.'
68*{'text': 'Lucius Clodius Macer revolts against emperor Nero.'
68*{'text': 'Marcus Ulpius Trajanus
68*{'text': 'Trajan moves to Scythopolis and crosses the Jordan River with Legio X Fretensis.'
68*{'text': 'The Roman Senate declares Nero as a persona non grata.'
68*{'date': 'Winter'
column2: 'text': 'Titus sets up camp at Jericho and the Romans cut off escape routes toward Jerusalem.'

column1: 68*{'text': 'An iron chain suspension bridge is constructed in China.'
68*{'text': 'Buddhism officially arrives in China with the building of the White Horse Temple.'
68*{'text': 'Ignatius of Antioch becomes the third bishop of Antioch.'
68*{'text': 'The Gospel of Mark is written (approximate date).'
68*{'text': 'The Essenes place the Dead Sea Scrolls in the caves at Qumran.'
69*{'date': 'January 1'
column2: 'text': 'The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuses to swear loyalty to Galba.'

column1: 69*{'date': 'January 10'
column2: 'text': 'Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is adopted by Galba and appointed to deputy Roman Emperor.'

column1: 69*{'date': 'January 15'
column2: 'text': 'Galba and his adopted son Piso are murdered by the Praetorian Guard on the Roman Forum.'

column1: 69*{'text': 'Otho seizes power in Rome
column3: and reigns for three months before committing suicide.'

column1: 69*{'text': 'Marcus Trebellius Maximus
column3: is forced the flee to Gaul after a mutiny of Legio XX Valeria Victrix at Deva Victrix (Chester).'

column1: 69*{'text': 'Marcus Vettius Bolanus becomes the new governor of Britain and faced a second insurrection of Venutius
69*{'date': 'July 1'
column2: 'text': 'Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as emperor.'

69*{'date': 'December 22'

column1: 69*{'text': 'Josephus
column3: is dragged before Vespasian and becomes his historian.'

column1: 69*{'text': 'Legio I Macriana liberatrix is disbanded.'
69*{'text': 'The Flavian dynasty starts.'
2*{'text': 'Gaius Caesar meets with Phraates V

column1: 2*{'text': 'Publius Alfenus Varus and Publius Vinicius become Roman Consuls.'

column2: restoring marquess titles to past imperial princes and introducing a pension system for retired officials.'

6*{'text': 'Herod Archelaus
column5: is deposed and banished to Vienne in Gaul.'

6*{'text': 'Publius Sulpicius Quirinius becomes Governor of Syria and nominally of Judea.'

column4: and supported by the Pharisee Zadok.'

column1: 6*{'text': 'Augustus banishes Agrippa Postumus

6*{'date': 'January'
column2: 'text': 'Some Chinese fear for the life of the young
column3: ailing Emperor Ping Di as the planet Mars disappears behind the moon this month.'

column1: 6*{'date': 'February 3'
column3: Ping Di dies of unexpected causes at age 14; Wang Mang alone selects the new emperor
column6: starting the Jushe era of the Han Dynasty.'

column1: 6*{'text': "The imperial Liu clan suspect the intentions of Wang Mang and foment agrarian rebellions during the course of Ruzi Ying's reign."
98*{'text': 'Emperor Nerva suffers a stroke during a private audience.'
98*{'date': 'January 27'
column2: 'text': 'Nerva is succeeded by his adopted son Trajan.'

column1: 98*{'text': 'Trajan is the first Roman Emperor born in Italica
98*{'text': 'The informers used by Domitian to support his tyranny are expelled from Rome.'
98*{'text': 'Tacitus finishes his Germania (approximate date).'
98*{'text': 'The silver content of the Roman denarius rises to 93 percent under emperor Trajan
91*{'text': 'Manius Acilius Glabrio and Marcus Ulpius Traianus become Roman Consul.'
91*{'text': 'Pliny the Younger is named a tribunus plebis.'
91*{'text': 'The Chinese government reestablishes the Protectorate of the Western Regions.'
91*{'text': 'Rome is described by Statius in his poems.'
90*{'text': 'The Romans build a small garrison in the suburbs of modern Regensburg (approximate date).'
90*{'text': "Pliny the Younger's appointment as urban quaestor ends."
90*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian and Nerva are Roman Consuls.'
90*{'text': 'Cologne becomes the capital of Germania Inferior.'
90*{'text': 'A humiliating peace is bought by Domitian from Decebalus of Dacia.'
90*{'text': 'Artabanus III king of Parthia dies after a 10-year period in which he has challenged the suzerainty of Pacorus II
column2: who will continue his reign until 105 AD.'

column1: 90*{'text': 'Young Flavian Woman is made.'
90*{'text': 'The Roman epic poet Gaius Valerius Flaccus dies
column2: having written works that include the Argonautica
column3: describing the voyage of Jason and the Argonauts to retrieve the Golden Fleece from the mythical land of Colchis.'

column1: 93*{'text': 'Pliny the Younger is named a Praetor.'
93*{'text': 'Josephus completes his Jewish Antiquities (or in 94).'
93*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian persecutes the Christians.'
93*{'text': 'The Xianbei incorporates 100

92*{'text': 'The Roman army moves into Mesopotamia.'
92*{'text': 'A coalition of Dacians and Rhoxolani Sarmatians completely slaughtered the Legio XXI Rapax at Tropaeum Traiani

column1: 95*{'text': 'Emperor Domitian and Titus Flavius Clemens become Roman Consul.'

94*{'text': 'The Roman poet Statius retires to Naples from Rome.'
97*{'date': 'October 28'
column2: 'text': 'Emperor Nerva recalls his general Marcus Ulpius Trajanus
column4: from the German frontier and is forced by the Praetorian Guard to adopt him as his successor.'

column1: 97*{'text': 'Tacitus advances to consulship.'
97*{'text': 'The Roman colony of Cuicul is started in Numidia.'
97*{'text': 'Nerva recognizes the Sanhedrin of Jamnia as an official governmental body of the Jews
column2: and the patriarch or nasi is designated as the representative of the Jewish people in Rome.'

column1: 97*{'text': 'Pope Evaristus succeeds Pope Clement I as the fifth pope (according to Catholic tradition; none of the Popes until the mid second century is certain).'
96*{'date': 'September 18'
column2: 'text': 'Emperor Domitian is stabbed to death by a freedman at age 44 after a 15-year reign in a palace conspiracy involving officers of the Praetorian Guard.'

column1: 96*{'text': 'Nerva is declared emperor by the Senate as the new ruler of the Roman Empire.'
96*{'text': 'Marcus Ulpius Traianus becomes governor of Upper Germany.'

11*{'text': 'Germania Inferior and the Rhine are secured by Germanicus.'
11*{'text': 'Emperor Augustus abandons his plan to create a defensive border at the Elbe
column2: in order to reinforce the Roman defense along the Rhine and the Danube.'

column1: 11*{'text': 'Artabanus II of the Arsacid Dynasty becomes ruler of Parthia.'
10*{'text': 'Publius Cornelius Dolabella is a Roman consul.'
10*{'text': 'Illyria is divided into Pannonia and Dalmatia.'
10*{'text': 'Senatus consultum Silanianum is adopted.'
10*{'text': 'The usurper Wang Mang (who rules during a brief interregnum known as the Xin Dynasty) outlaws the private purchase and use of crossbows.'
10*{'text': 'The Greek dynasty in Bactria is extinguished.'
10*{'text': 'Ovid completes Tristia (the "Sorrows"
column2: 5 books) and Epistulae ex Ponto (Letters from the Black Sea
column3: 4 books) describing the sadness of banishment.'

column1: 13*{'text': 'Abgarus of Edessa is reinstalled as king of Osroene.'
13*{'text': 'The Senate passes a senatus consultum restricting the reduced Vigintisexviri to the Ordo Equester.'
13*{'text': 'Tiberius makes his triumphant procession through Rome after the siege of Germany.'
13*{'text': 'Strabo publishes his book on the shape of the Earth.'
12*{'text': 'Annius Rufus is appointed Prefect of Judea.'
12*{'text': 'Augustus orders a major invasion of Germany beyond the Rhine.'
12*{'text': 'Germanicus and Gaius Fonteius Capito become Roman Consuls.'
12*{'text': 'Quirinius returns from Judea to become a counselor to Tiberius.'
12*{'text': 'The Armenian Artaxiad Dynasty is overthrown by the Romans.'
12*{'text': 'Ovid stops writing Fasti because of the lack of resources (being far from the libraries of Rome).'
15*{'text': 'Emona (currently Ljubljana) is founded by Legio XV Apollinaris.'
15*{'text': 'Germanicus fights a drawn battle with Arminius in the Teutoburg Forest.'
15*{'text': 'Germanicus captures Thusnelda
15*{'text': 'Legio XXI Rapax is stationed in Regensburg.'
15*{'text': 'Valerius Gratus is appointed Prefect of Iudaea.'
15*{'text': 'The river Tiber floods parts of Rome.'
15*{'text': 'Biography of Augustus by Nicholas of Damascus is published.'
14*{'text': 'Augustus dies and is declared to be a god.'
14*{'text': 'Tacitus reports that the town and port of Nauportus has been plundered by a mutinous Roman legion that was sent there to build roads and bridges.'
14*{'text': 'Tiberius succeeds his stepfather Augustus as Emperor of the Roman Empire.'
14*{'text': 'Germanicus is appointed commander of the forces in Germany
column2: beginning a campaign that will end in 16.'

column2: a German tribe on the upper Ruhr river

column1: 14*{'text': 'A census indicates that there are 4

14*{'text': 'The Hellenistic period ends
column2: according to some scholars (usual date 31 BC).'
'text': 'Germanicus returns to Rome as conquering hero
column3: he celebrates a triumph for his victories over the Cherusci
column4: Chatti and other German tribes west of the Elbe.'

column1: 17*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius sends Germanicus to the east in order to lead a military campaign against Parthia.'

17*{'text': 'Maroboduus
column3: is defeated by Arminius and his Germanic tribes.'

column1: 17*{'text': 'Tacfarinas
column2: Numidian deserter from the Roman army
column3: begins a guerrilla war against the Romans.'

column1: 17*{'text': 'Herod Antipas
column3: builds on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee
column4: the city Tiberias in honor of Tiberius.'

column1: 17*{'text': 'An earthquake in Anatolia destroys the city of Sardis.'
16*{'text': "A Roman army of 50
column2: 000 men commanded by Germanicus gains a great victory at Idistaviso
column3: defeating the German war chief Arminius and recovering the lost eagles of Varus' legions."

19*{'text': 'First flying machine
18*{'text': 'Emperor Tiberius and Germanicus are Roman Consuls.'
18*{'text': 'A vexillatio (sub-unit) of Legio III Augusta is destroyed by an ambush in Africa.'
18*{'text': 'The German chieftain Arminius destroys the kingdom of the Marcomanni.'
18*{'date': 'Winter'
column3: as new commander in chief for the Roman East.'

column1: 18*{'text': 'Gnaeus Calpurnius Piso
column3: ignored the order of Germanicus to send Syrian-based legions
column4: including Legio VI Ferrata and Legio X Fretensis
column5: to Armenia to back him in his planned coronation of Artaxias III.'

column1: 18*{'text': 'Germanicus conclude a peace treaty with Artabanus II of Parthia
column2: in which he is recognized as king and friend of Rome.'

column1: 48*{'text': 'The emperor Claudius invests Agrippa II with the office of superintendent of the Temple in Jerusalem.'
48*{'text': 'Vitellius is a Roman Consul.'
48*{'text': 'Publius Ostorius Scapula
column3: announces his intention to disarm all Britons south and east of the Trent and Severn.'

column1: 48*{'text': 'Gallic nobles are admitted to the Roman Senate.'
48*{'text': 'The Hsiung-nu empire dissolves.'
48*{'text': 'The emperor of China
column3: restores Chinese domination of Inner Mongolia.'

column1: 49*{'text': 'Emperor Claudius marries his niece Agrippina the Younger (approximate date).'
49*{'text': "Seneca the Younger becomes Nero's tutor."
49*{'text': 'Melankomas is the boxing champion at the 207th Olympic Games.'
49*{'text': 'Nero becomes engaged to Claudia Octavia

49*{'text': "New Testament book Paul's Epistle to the Galatians is probably written."
46*{'text': 'The settlement at Celje gets municipal rights and is named municipium Claudia Celeia.'
46*{'text': 'Dobruja is annexed into Roman Moesia.'
46*{'text': 'A census shows that there are more than 6
46*{'text': 'Rome and its northeast border are reunited by the Danube Road.'
46*{'text': 'A drought and an invasion of locusts hit the Mongolian steppes
column2: causing a famine and a revolt at Xiongnu.'

column1: 47*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder sees military service in Germany.'
47*{'text': 'Publius Ostorius Scapula becomes governor of Britain
47*{'text': 'Claudius founds the city Forum Claudii Vallensium (modern Martigny) in the Alpes Poeninae (Switzerland).'
47*{'text': 'Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo is made commander of the Roman army in Germania Inferior
column2: he conquers the Chauci and fights against the Cherusci and Frisians.'

column1: 47*{'text': 'Corbulo orders the construction of the canal Fossa Corbulonis
column2: between the Rhine and Meuse in the Netherlands
column3: which connects the city Forum Hadriani (Voorburg).'

column1: 47*{'text': 'Cauci pirates led by the Roman deserter Gannascus ravage the Gallic coast; Corbulo uses the Rhine fleet against them.'
47*{'text': 'Claudius revives the censorship and ludi saeculares
column2: and he organises the order of the Haruspices with 60 members.'

column1: 47*{'text': 'Musselburgh is founded in Roman Britain (Scotland).'
47*{'text': 'Ananias becomes high priest in Judaea.'
47*{'text': 'Paul starts his evangelistic work.'
44*{'text': 'Gaius Sallustius Crispus Passienus and Titus Statilius Taurus become Roman consuls.'
44*{'text': 'The emperor Claudius returns from his British campaign in triumph
column2: the southeast part of Britannia now held by the Roman Empire
column3: but the war will rage for another decade and a half.'

column1: 44*{'text': 'Boudicca marries Prasutagus
column2: king of the British Celtic tribe the Iceni.'

column1: 44*{'text': 'Mauretania becomes a Roman province.'
44*{'text': 'The Isle of Rhodes returns to the Roman Empire.'
44*{'text': 'Judaea is controlled by Roman governors.'
44*{'text': 'Cuspius Fadus
column3: suppress the revolt of Theudas who is decapitated.'

column1: 44*{'text': 'Pomponius Mela writes De situ orbis

45*{'text': 'Galba becomes the commander of Legio III Augusta.'
45*{'text': 'Salzburg (Juvavum) is awarded the status of a Roman municipium.'
45*{'text': 'The emperor Claudius expels the Jews from Rome.'
45*{'text': 'Emperor Claudius founds Savaria
column2: today the Hungarian city of Szombathely.'

column1: 45*{'text': 'The Senate holds consultations regarding real estate speculation in Rome.'
45*{'text': 'The wealthy freedman C. Lusius Storax dies.'
45*{'text': 'Paul of Tarsus begins his missionary travels
column2: according to one traditional dating scheme.'

column1: 42*{'text': 'The territories of the current Algeria and Morocco become a Roman province.'
42*{'text': 'The Dalmatian legate
column3: revolts but his troops defect and his rebellion quickly withers.'

column1: 42*{'text': 'Claudius begins construction of Portus
column2: the harbour bears a lighthouse and is sited on the right bank of the Tiber.'

column1: 42*{'text': 'Suro becomes the first king of Geumgwan Gaya in the Korean peninsula.'
42*{'text': 'The Chinese General Ma Yuan represses the rebellion of the Trung sisters in Tonkin.'
43*{'text': 'The Roman conquest of Britain begins.'
43*{'text': 'The Romans capture a Brythonic settlement at Kent
column2: and rename it Durovernum Cantiacorum (modern Canterbury).'

column1: 43*{'text': 'Claudius annexes Lycia in Asia Minor
column2: combining it with Pamphylia as a Roman province.'

column1: 43*{'text': 'The Romans now have complete control of the Mediterranean.'
43*{'text': 'Warfare begins between the northern and southern Huns.'
43*{'text': 'The warrior Trung Sisters commit suicide after their resistance is defeated at Nam Viet in Vietnam.'
43*{'text': 'Vietnam is designated a province of China.'
43*{'text': 'Pomponius Mela
column3: writes De situ orbis libri (probable date).'

column1: 40*{'text': 'The emperor Caligula is consul without colleague.'
40*{'text': 'Caligula starts on a campaign to conquer Britain
40*{'text': 'Noricum and Mauretania are incorporated into the Roman Empire.'
40*{'text': 'Caligula reforms the principatus into a Hellenistic Autocracy.'
40*{'text': 'The Germanic Quadi tribe begin settling in present-day Moravia and Slovakia.'
40*{'text': 'The Vietnamese Trung sisters rebel against the rule of the Chinese Emperor Guangwu of Han.'
40*{'text': 'Philo teaches that all men are born free.'
40*{'text': 'An early Christian church is erected at Corinth (most probable date).'
41*{'text': 'Caligula
column2: known for his eccentricity and cruel despotism
column3: is assassinated by his disgruntled Praetorian Guards.'

column1: 41*{'text': 'Claudius succeeds his nephew Caligula as Emperor.'
41*{'text': 'Claudius makes Agrippa king of Judea.'
41*{'text': 'Messalina
column3: persuades Claudius to have Seneca the Younger banished to Corsica on a charge of adultery with Julia Livilla.'

column1: 41*{'text': 'Claudius restores religious freedom to Jews throughout the empire
column2: but prohibits Jews in Rome from proselytising.'

column1: 41*{'text': 'An attack across the Rhine by the Germans is stopped by the Romans.'
41*{'text': 'Emperor Guangwu of the Han Dynasty deposes his wife
column4: and creates his consort Yin Lihua empress in her place.'

column1: 41*{'text': 'The disciples of Jesus form communities after the Diaspora
41*{'text': 'The death of Caligula saves the Jewish people from being punished for resisting orders to worship his statue in the Temple of Jerusalem.'
1*{'text': 'Tiberius
1*{'text': 'Gaius Caesar and Lucius Aemilius Paullus are appointed consuls.'

column2: daughter of Antonia Minor and Nero Claudius Drusus

column1: 1*{'text': 'Quirinius becomes a chief advisor to Gaius in Armenia.'

1*{'text': 'Confucius is given his first royal title (posthumous name) of Lord Baochengxun Ni.'

column1: 1*{'text': 'Amanishakheto

column2: as assigned by Dionysius Exiguus in his anno Domini era according to at least one scholar.'

column1: 5*{'text': 'Rome acknowledges Cunobelinus
5*{'text': 'The Germanic Tribes of Cimbri and Charydes send ambassadors to Rome.'

column5: weapons and privileges bestowed only on those in the most intimate relationship with the emperor.'

column1: 9*{'text': 'Lui Kuai
column3: attacks the Dukedom of Fuchong under his brother Liu Ying.'

column1: 9*{'text': 'Wang Mang founds the short-lived Xin Dynasty in China (until 25).'
9*{'text': 'Claudius marries Plautia Urgulanilla following the death of Livia Medullina.'
9*{'text': 'Illyria is turned into a province after the Great Illyrian Revolt is defeated.'
9*{'text': 'The Rhine River is established as the boundary between the Latin and German speaking worlds
column2: following the defeat of the Roman army
column4: at the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest.'

column1: 9*{'text': 'Legio II Augusta
column3: and XIII Gemina move to Germany to replace Legio XIX and the others destroyed at Teutoburg.'

column1: 9*{'text': 'Ovid is banished to Tomis.'
9*{'text': 'Pannonia (modern-day Hungary) submits to Roman rule.'
9*{'text': 'The Catuvellauni attack the Trinovantes and capture Camulodunum.'
9*{'text': 'Ovid completes Ibis (single poem).'
77*{'text': 'Gnaeus Julius Agricola is named governor of Britannia
77*{'text': 'Agricola subdues the Ordovices in Wales and pursues the remnants of the tribe to Anglesey
column2: the holy island of the Druids.'

column1: 77*{'text': 'The Caledonian tribes in Scotland are formed in a confederacy of 30
column2: 000 warriors under the leadership of Calgacus.'

column1: 77*{'text': 'A Roman squadron
column3: explores the north of Scotland for the first time
column4: discovering the Orkney and Shetland Islands.'

column1: 77*{'date': 'Winter'
column2: 'text': 'Agricola conquers Anglesey and disperses his army to their winter quarters.'

column1: 77*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder publishes the first ten books of Naturalis Historia.'
77*{'text': 'The Romans develop a simple method of distillation.'
76*{'text': 'Emperor Vespasianus Augustus and Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consul.'

column2: establishing a fortress at Caerleon or Isca Augusta for Legio II Augusta and makes a network of smaller forts for his auxiliary forces.'

column1: 76*{'text': 'First year of Jianchu era of the Chinese Han Dynasty.'

75*{'text': 'Emperor Vespasianus and his son Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consul.'

column2: also known as the Forum of Vespasian

column1: 75*{'text': 'Sextus Julius Frontinus becomes governor of Britannia and make his headquarters in Isca Augusta (Wales).'

column2: Legio II Augusta is moved to the border of the River Usk.'

column1: 75*{'text': 'Caerwent is founded by the Romans as the market town of Venta Silurum

74*{'text': 'The Black Forest region is reattached to the Roman Empire.'
74*{'text': 'The Chinese reestablish a protectorate of the Western Regions.'
73*{'date': 'Spring'
column2: 'text': 'The Roman governor Lucius Flavius Silva lays siege to Masada
column3: the last outpost of the Jewish rebels following the end in 70 of the First Jewish-Roman War (Jewish Revolt).'

column1: 73*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder serves as procurator in Hispania Tarraconensis.'
73*{'text': 'Titus Flavius Domitianus becomes Roman Consul.'
73*{'text': 'Emperor Vespasian begins conquest of territory east of the upper Rhine and south of the Main.'
73*{'date': 'February'
column2: 'text': 'The Chinese Han Dynasty launches a major campaign against the Xiongnu
column3: whom they confront in the Battle of Yiwulu in the Kumul oasis
column4: an ultimate Han military victory led by General Dou Gu (d. 88).'

column1: 73*{'text': 'Ban Chao (Pan-Ch’ao)
column3: imposes a Chinese protectorate on the kings of Lop Nor and Khotan in the Tarim basin
column4: with the aim of controlling the Silk Road.'

column1: 72*{'text': 'Antiochus IV of Syria is deposed by emperor Vespasian.'
72*{'text': 'The Romans lay siege to Masada
column2: a desert fortress held by Jewish victims of the Sicarii.'

column1: 71*{'text': 'The Romans establish a fortress at York (Eboracum)
column2: as a base for their northern forces.'

column1: 71*{'text': 'Emperor Vespasian and Marcus Cocceius Nerva are Roman Consuls.'
71*{'text': 'Cerialis defeats Claudius Civilis at the Battle of Treves
71*{'text': 'Titus is awarded with a triumph
column2: accompanied by Vespasian and his brother Titus Flavius Domitian.'

column1: 71*{'text': 'Titus is made praetorian prefect of the Praetorian Guard and receives pro-consular command and also tribunician power
column2: all of which indicates that Vespasian will follow the hereditary tradition of succession.'

column1: 71*{'text': 'Reign of Rabel II
71*{'text': 'Mithraism begins to spread throughout the Roman Empire.'
70*{'text': 'Emperor Vespasian and his son Titus Caesar Vespasian become Roman Consuls.'
70*{'text': 'Panic strikes Rome as adverse winds delay grain shipments from Africa and Egypt
70*{'text': 'Sextus Julius Frontinus is praetor of Rome.'
70*{'text': 'Pliny the Elder serves as procurator in Gallia Narbonensis.'

column2: 'text': "Titus opens a full-scale assault on Jerusalem
column3: he concentrates his attack on the city's Third Wall to the northwest."

column2: 'text': 'The Third Wall of Jerusalem collapse and the Jews withdrew from Bezetha to the Second Wall
'text': 'Titus and his Roman legions breach the Second Wall of Jerusalem.'

column1: 70*{'date': 'July 20'
column2: 'text': 'Titus storms the Fortress of Antonia north of the Temple Mount.'

column1: 70*{'date': 'August 4'
column2: 'text': 'Titus destroys the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem.'

column1: 70*{'date': 'August–September'
column2: 'text': "Titus assaults the Temple Mount and detroys Herod's Palace in the Upper City of Jerusalem."

column1: 70*{'text': 'Neapolis (present day Nablus) is founded in Iudaea Province.'
70*{'text': 'Naval clashes on the Rhine during the Batavian Revolt; crew of a captured Roman flagship is imprisoned at Augusta Treverorum (modern Trier).'
70*{'text': 'India sees the end of the Hellenistic dynasties.'
70*{'text': 'Avignon becomes the seat of a bishopric.'
79*{'text': 'Vespasianus Augustus and Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consul.'
79*{'date': 'August 24'
79*{'text': 'Emperor Titus dedicates the famous Roman Colosseum.'
79*{'text': 'Chester is founded as a castrum or Roman fort with the name Deva Victrix.'
79*{'text': 'Gnaeus Julius Agricola enters Caledonia (modern Scotland) but is resisted by the Caledonians.'
79*{'text': 'Agricola founds Mamucium
column2: a frontier fort and settlement in the North West of England.'

column1: 79*{'text': 'A commission of scholars canonizes the text of works of Confucius and his school.'
78*{'text': 'Gnaeus Julius Agricola replaces Sextus Julius Frontinus as governor of Roman Britain.'
78*{'text': 'Emperor Kadphises of the Kushan Empire
column2: sends a delegation to Rome for seeking support against the Parthians.'

column1: 78*{'text': 'This is the base year (year zero) of the Saka era used by some Hindu calendars
78*{'text': 'Kanishka
column2: reigns over the Tocharian Empire of Kusana (Afghanistan and Northern India).'

column1: 78*{'text': 'Pacorus II is king of Parthia (78–115).'
78*{'text': 'The philosopher Wang Chong (Wang-Tchoung) claims all phenomena have material causes.'
